channel.title: World Wide Webber on World Wide Webber
channel.description: Recent content in World Wide Webber on World Wide Webber

item.title: Social Media
item.description:
Twitter

Nowadays I have a relatively quiet Twitter account which is mixture of chatter with friends and colleagues, some computing science things, and a dash of left politics.

Following the example of Jonthan Dowland my Twitter feed has a sliding window of 90 days worth of tweets. I like Twitter (somewhat) for conversations, but as a system of record much less so.

Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat etc.

I’m not on any other social media sites. I prefer email to Facebook and have a face for radio rather than Instagram. If you meet a Jim Webber on these platforms, it’s not me.

item.title: Refereed Publications
item.description:
Academic Book Chapters

(The technical books I’ve authored are on my books page.)

Realising Service Oriented Architectures Using Web Services

Jim Webber and Savas Parastatidis, Service-Oriented Computing: The Web Services Phenomenon, MIT Press 2008.

Protocol-based Integration using SSDL and Pi-Calculus

Woodman, S., Parastatidis, S. and Webber, J. In Workflows for E-science: Scientific Workflows for Grids Taylor, I. .J., Deelman, E., Gannon, D.B. and Shields, M. (eds.), pp 227-243, ISBN 978-1-84628-519-6, Springer-Verlag 2007.

Visual Object-Oriented Development of Parallel Applications (Ph.D. Thesis)

Webber, J. Department of Computing Science, Newcastle University upon Tyne, 2000.

Academic Journals

An Architect’s Guide to Developing Enterprise Web Services

Webber, J., CSI Communications, Volume 29, Issue 9, pp. 15-20, March 2006.

Asynchronous Messaging between Web Services Using SSDL

Parastatidis, S., Woodman, S., Webber, J., Kuo, D., Greenfield, P., IEEE Internet Computing, vol. 10, no. 1, pp. 26-39, January/February, 2006.

Grid Computing using Web Services Technologies

Parastatidis S., Watson, P., Webber, J., 6th Thematic Workshop of the EU Network of Excellence DELOS, Cagliari, Italy, June 24-25, 2004, Lecture Notes in Computer Science, Springer-Verlag, ISSN: 0302-9743.

WS-GAF: a framework for building Grid applications using Web Services

Coordinating Business Transactions on the Web

Visual, Object-Oriented Development of Parallel Applications

Webber, J. and Lee, P.A., Journal of Visual Languages and Computing, Volume 12, Issue 2, pp 145-161, Academic Press, ISSN: 1045-926X, 2001.

Conference Proceedings

Towards a Horizontally Scalable Graph Database

Jim Webber, Proceedings of the European Data Forum, June 6-7 2012, Copenhagen, Denmark.

The Role of Hypermedia in Distributed System Development

Savas Parastatidis, Jim Webber, Guilherme Silveira and Ian Robinson, Proceedings of the First International Workshop on RESTful Design (WS-REST 2010), at WWW 2010

Soya: a Programming Model and Runtime Environment for Component Composition using SSDL

Expressing and Reasoning about Service Contracts in Service-Oriented Computing

Kuo, D. et al., Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Web Services 2006, pp 915-918, July 2006

Secure and Provable Service Support for Human-Intensive Real-Estate Processes

Emerson Ribeiro de Mello et al, Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Services Computing (SCC’06), pp. 495-504

Proceedings of the First International Workshop on the Design of Service-Oriented Applications (WDSOA’05)

Chung, J.Y., Feuerlicht, G., Webber J. (eds), Amsterdam, 2005. IBM Research Report RC23819.

Assessing the Risk and Value of Adopting Emerging and Unstable Web Services Specifications

Parastatidis, S. and Webber, J., Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Services Computing, Shanghai, China, 2004.

The WS-GAF Registry Service

Parastatidis S., and Webber, J., 2nd Workshop on Building Service-based Grids, GGF 11 Honolulu, Hawaii, USA, July 2004.

Grid Computing using Web Services Technologies

Parastatidis, S., Watson, , P., and Webber, J., Proceedings of the DELOS Workshop on Digital Library Architectures, S. Margherita di Pula, Cagliari, Italy, June 2004.

The Misplaced Comma: Programmers’ Tales and Traditions

Marshall, L. and Webber, J., Proceedings of the 14th Annual Workshop of the Psychology of Programming Interest Group, 2002.

Visual, Object-Oriented Development of Parallel Applications

Webber, J. and Lee, P.A., Proceedings of Satellite Workshop on Visual Methods for Parallel and Distributed Programming, IEEE Visual Languages, Seattle, USA, September 2000.

Gotos Considered Harmful and other Programmer’s Taboos

Marshall, L. and Webber, J. Proceedings of the 12th Annual Workshop of the Psychology of Programming Interest Group, 2000.

Vorlon: A Visual Object-Oriented Approach to Parallel Application Development

Webber, J. Proceedings of the Doctoral Symposium, 13th IEEE Conference on Automated Software Engineering, 1998.

Service-Oriented, Distributed, High-Performance Computing

Parastatidis S. and Webber, J., Microsoft Architecture Journal, Vol. 1, Issue 5, July 2005.

Stateful Interactions in Web Services:

A Comparison of WS-Context and WS-ResourceFramework Webber, J., Parastatidis S., Little, M.C., Web Services Journal, Vol. 4, Issue 5, May 2004.

Why WSDL is not Yet Another Object IDL

Webber, J., and Parastatidis S., Web Services Journal, Vol. 4, Issue 4, April 2004.

Horses for Courses: Services, Objects, and Loose Coupling

Webber, J., and Parastatidis S., Web Services Journal, Vol. 4, Issue 1, January 2004.

Introducing WS-CAF

Building Transactional Web Services with OASIS BTP

Webber J., Web Services Journal, Vol. 2, Issue 10, October 2002. Continued Vol.2, Issue 11, November 2002.

The Smart Money s on OASIS BTP (Guest Editorial)

Webber J., Web Services Journal, Vol. 2, Issue 4, April 2002.

Making Web Services Work

Webber, J., et al, Application Development Advisor, Volume 5, Issue 9, pp 68-71 SIGS Ltd., ISSN: 1369-4200, 2001

Secure and Provable Service Support for Human-Intensive Real-Estate Processes

Ribeiro de Mello, E., Parastatidis, S., Reinecke, P., Smith, C., van Moorsel, A., Webber, J. CS-TR: 960, School of Computing Science, Newcastle University, May  2006.

Assessing the Risk and Value of Adopting Emerging and Unstable Web Services Specifications

Parastatidis, S. and Webber, J. CS-TR: 851, School of Computing Science, Newcastle University, July 2004.

Using Web Services to Build Grid Applications – The “No Risk” WS-GAF Profile

Parastatidis, S., Webber, J. and Watson, P. CS-TR: 850, School of Computing Science, Newcastle University, June 2004.

A Grid Application Framework based on Web Services Specifications and Practices

Taxonomy for Visual Parallel Programming

Lee, P. A. and Webber, J., CS-TR: 793, School of Computing Science, Newcastle University, April 2003.

item.title: Books by Jim Webber
item.description:
Graph Databases

By Ian Robinson, Jim Webber and Emil Eifrem

Graph databases – like Neo4j – are a powerful tool for storing and querying highly connected data. Indeed Neo4j can be thousands of times faster than relational databases for such connected data, making it a popular for managing complex data across many domains from finance to social, and telecoms to geospatial. In this book, Ian, Emil, and I explain what a graph database is and how it can be used to gain insight into business critical data. We show how modern graph databases are an excellent choice for both OLTP and OLAP data stores and demonstrate the myriad of use-cases for the Neo4j database.

REST in Practice

By Jim Webber, Savas Parastatidis, and Ian Robinson

Does the REST architectural style really present a viable alternative for building distributed systems and enterprise-class applications? In this book, Savas, Ian and I provide a down-to-earth explanation of REST and demonstrate how to develop simple and elegant distributed systems using Web techniques and technology. Throughout the book, we use Web technologies and patterns to solve the needs of a typical company as it grows from modest beginnings to become a global enterprise, from simple CRUD applications through to hypermedia-driven business processes. We’ll also demonstrate how those enterprise staples – security and event-driven systems – are easy to implement with Web tools.

Buy: Amazon (US), Amazon (UK)

Developing Enterprise Web Services: An Architect’s Guide

By Sandeep Chatterjee and Jim Webber

This was one of the first books to demonstrate how to build (WS-*) Web Services with enterprise-class reliability, and performance. This book takes a no-nonsense view of architecting and constructing enterprise-class Web services and applications. The authors assess the state of the art of the Web services platform circa 2004, offering best practices and new architectural patterns for taking advantage of Web Services.

While the architectural patterns in this book generally remain worthwhile today, the protocols and standards covered are now looking somewhat out of date, especially since there is a strong groundswell towards building RESTful systems on the Web rather than tunnelling through HTTP with clever XML payloads.

Buy: Amazon (US), Amazon (UK)

item.title: Blog being resurrected very soon
item.description: I’ll port over all my old blog posts one of these days…
